metadata.title: Preparation and characterization of active emulsified films based on chitosan-carboxymethyl cellulose containing zinc oxide nano particles

sections.text:
Active nanocomposites based on carboxymethyl cellulose-chitosan-oleic acid (CMC-CH-OL) incorporated with different concentrations (0.5-2 wt.%) of zinc oxide nanoparticles (ZnO NPs) were produced by casting method. The effects of ZnO NPs on the morphological, mechanical, thermal, physical and antifungal properties of the films were studied. New interaction between ZnO NPs and polymer matrix were confirmed by Fourier Transform infrared. After addition of ZnO NPs, tensile strength, lightness (L*) and thermal stability decreased however, elongation at break, contact angle, a* (greenness) and b* (yellowness) of the nanocomposite films increased in comparison to the films without nano-filler. UV transmittance at 280 nm decreased from 17.3% to 0.2, 0.1 and 0.1 for the nanocomposite films containing 0.5, 1 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs, respectively, suggesting higher UV blocking properties. Disc diffusion test showed
considerable antifungal properties of the active nanocomposite films against Aspergillus niger, especially in CMC-CH-OL-ZnO 2 wt.% by more than 40% fungal growth inhibition.
Keywords: Zinc oxide nano particle; ; ; , Chitosan, Carboxymethyl cellulose, Antifungal activity
1. Introduction
Microbial contamination of food is a serious problem which causes health problems for consumers and decreases food shelf life [1]. Mostly, synthetic preservatives are added into the food for controlling microbial growth. However, due to probable problems of synthetic preservatives to human health, consumers are looking for bio-based and generally recognized as safe (GRAS) preservatives to control the microbial growth of food [2]. Antimicrobial active packaging is a new method to increase the shelf life of food without direct addition of antimicrobial agents into the food. Active food packaging includes interaction between food and packaging material, which inhibits microbial growth of food and increases its shelf life [3].
Nanotechnology provides comprehensive opportunity to improve food packaging, and can increase the shelf life of food as well as improve the properties of packaging material. There has been much interest in the use of metal nanoparticles in this type of packaging, due to fact that metal oxide nanoparticles show excellent antimicrobial properties [4]. Among them, application of gold and silver as antimicrobial agent, is limited due to their high price [5]. Zinc oxide is an interesting agent in food and pharmacy fields due to its nutritional properties, effective antimicrobial properties at low concentrations, high stability against high temperatures, non-toxicity, and good UV absorbance properties. Also, it is known as a GRAS compound by Food and Drug Administration [6]. It is worth noting that because ZnO NPs use as nutrient agent, thus addition of it to the film packaging and its probable diffusion to the food products are not harmful to human health [7]. The effective antimicrobial properties of ZnO NPs in active films have been reported for starch films against Staphylococcus aureus [8];
polylactic acid-ZnO NPs nanocomposite films against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus [5]; chitosan-neem oil based film against E. coli [9]; and sodium alginate-gum acacia hydrogels versus Pseudomonas aerigunosa and Bacillus cereus [10]. The main reason for superior antimicrobial properties of metal nanoparticles is connected to their high surface area [11]. Aspergillus and Penicillium species are among the major spoiler fungal strains, which limit the shelf life of food products by production of toxic mycotoxins, off flavor, bad appearance etc. Thus, it is important to study the antifungal effects of ZnO NPs [12], while few studies have been done on it. Incorporation of ZnO NPs in biopolymer matrix is not only for its antimicrobial effects, but also for enhancing the mechanical and barrier properties of the bio nanocomposites as filler [13]. Previous studies have shown that the ZnO NPs can improve the mechanical [6, 13], barrier [5, 8, 14, 15]; and thermal properties [9, 14] of nanocomposite films.
Biopolymers including polysaccharides and proteins have been increasingly paid attention in food packaging application due to their low cost and good film forming properties [16, 17, 18]. Chitosan is a linear cationic carbohydrate polymer, which derives from chitin [19]. Due to its superior film forming properties, antimicrobial properties, and biodegradability, chitosan is a promising biopolymer for active packaging. Reactive amino and hydroxyl functional groups in chitosan, capable it to blend with other polymers to improve the properties of them, as well as chelating metal ions such as Zn+2 [20]. Chitosan film is a good barrier to oxygen and CO2 at low relative humidity, due to its ordered and packed structure and high hydrophilicity [21]. However, low water barrier properties is one of the disadvantages of polysaccharide films like chitosan [22], which can be improved by blending chitosan with other polymers. Carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) is a linear water soluble derivative of cellulose, which is inexpensive, nontoxic and non-allergenic and frequently used in foods, cosmetics, pharma etc. [1, 23]. In addition, CMC films are transparent, thus blending of chitosan with CMC decrease the yellow appearance of chitosan films. In addition, a reduction in water barrier properties of
chitosan in chitosan/methylcellulose blend films have been observed [24]. Despite to the improvement in barrier properties of blend films compared to single films, they still show high sensitivity to water, hence incorporation of lipid compounds or other hydrophobic compounds is a promising way to overcome this problem [22]. Up to now, few studies have been reported on the CMC-CH based films [13, 25, 26]. As far as we know, there is no study with CMC-CHOL-ZnO NPs formulation. Thus, the aim of the present study is to produce active emulsified packaging film based on carboxymethyl cellulose-chitosan-oleic acid incorporated by ZnO NPs by the solution casting method and then, to study their physical and antifungal properties .
2. Material and methods
2.1. Materials Chitosan (low molecular weight, 20-300 cP, 50-190 k Da, deacetylation degree 75-85 %) and sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (high viscosity, 1500-3000 cP) were purchased from Sigma Aldrich (USA) and Caragum Parsian (Tehran, Iran), respectively. Analytical grade glycerol, oleic acid and tween 80 were obtained from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany), potato dextrose agar (PDA) from Merck Millipore (Darmstadt, Germany). All other products were of analytical grade. Zinc oxide NPs with average size of ˂25 nm was purchased from Sigma Aldrich (USA).

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of films
sections.text:
Films were elaborated by solution casting method. At first, 0.2 g of chitosan dispersed in acidic distilled water (0.5% v/v acetic acid) and stirred overnight. Afterwards, the pH was adjusted to around 6.8 by pouring drop by drop of NaOH solution (3 M). ZnO NPs powder at different concentrations (0.5, 1 and 2 wt.%) was solubilized in water and sonicated for 30 min. Then, CMC (0.4 g) was dissolved in distilled water (50 mL) contain ZnO NPs suspension and were mixed by magnetic stirrer for 1 h. Then, both solutions were mixed; tween 80 (0.2 mL) was added as an emulsifier and stirred again for 15 min. Oleic acid (0.3 mL) was then added, and the mixture, was homogenized by probe ultrasound (Bandelin Sonopuls, Germany) for 15 min
(31 KJ). Glycerol (0.3 mL) as the plasticizer of the film was added to the dispersions and stirred for 15 min and degassed under vacuum for 30 min in order to remove air bubbles from the dispersions. Then, about 50 mL of each dispersion was poured into the polystyrene petri-dishes (9 cm diameter) and dried at 25 °C for 72 h. Dried films were peeled and conditioned at 25 °C and 55% relative humidity before analysis.

sections.heading: 2.3. X-ray diffractometry (XRD)
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction patterns of the film samples was analyzed using an APD 2001 X-ray diffractometer (Ital Structures, Italy). The spectra were recorded using Cu-Kα radiation at a voltage of 40 kV and a current of 50 mA with scanning at ambient temperature from 2θ values from 2.5 to 60°, where θ is the angle of incidence of the X-ray beam on the sample. The size of the crystals was calculated according to the Scherrer equation (Eq. 1):
D= 𝐾𝜆
𝛽𝑐𝑜𝑠𝜃 (Eq.1)
Where, D is the crystal size, λ is the X-ray wavelength; K is Scherrer constant is 0.9; β is width at half maximum (FWHM), and θ is the Bragg diffraction angle [27]. Determination of Crystallinity index (%) was calculated according to the Segal Equation (Eq.2):
Crystallinity index = 𝐼𝑡−𝐼𝑎
𝐼𝑡 × 100 (Eq.2)
Where, It is the height of the (200) peak, represents both crystalline and amorphous regions; and Ia is the lowest height between the (200) and (110) peaks, which represents the amorphous region [27].

sections.heading: 2.4. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM)
sections.text:
Microstructure analysis of surfaces of the films was carried out using SEM technique in a (SEM) (TOPCON SM-200 SEM). The films deposited onto a copper holder with conductive
carbon paint and coated with gold under vacuum before observation. All samples were examined using low vacuum at a voltage of 20 KV.

sections.heading: 2.5. Attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transforms infrared (FTIR-ATR) spectroscopy
sections.text: ATR-FTIR spectra of the films were obtained using a FTIR spectrometer (PIKE technologies/Gladi Atrvertex 70, Bruker, France). Spectra were recorded at the absorbance mode from 4000 to 400 cm-1 with automatic signal gain (32 scans) at a resolution of 4 cm-1.

sections.heading: 2.6. Film thickness
sections.text: Film thickness was measured using a micrometer (Mitutoyo, 293-766-30, Tokyo, Japan). Reported values were the average of ten random locations for each film.

sections.heading: 2.7. Mechanical tests
sections.text:
Films were cut in dumbbelly forms (5 mm width × 60 mm long), later conditioned in a desiccator containing a saturated calcium nitrite solution at a relative humidity (RH) of 55% for 72 h at ambient temperature before measurements. Tensile strength (TS, MPa), Elongation-atbreak (EB, %) and Young modulus (YM, MPa) were measured by a tensile machine (Zwick/Roell model FR010, Germany) according to ASTM standard method D882-02 [28]. The initial grip separation was set at 50 mm and the crosshead speed at 5.0 mm/min. Mechanical tests measured five times for each film.
2.8. Contact angle
Contact angle of the surface of the films was measured by a Goniometer (Kruss DSA 100, Germany). Film strips (10 × 60 mm) were put on a movable sample stage and leveled horizontally; a drop of approximately 2 µL of distilled water was placed on the surface of the film using a micro-syringe. The contact angle was measured in a conditioned room by recording contact angle values. For each film, at least five replicates were tested.

sections.heading: 2.9. Color
sections.text:
L*, a*, b* color values of the films were recorded as the average of three replicates using a portable colorimeter (CR-300 Minolta Chroma Meter, Minolta Camera Co., Osaka, Japan). Films were placed on a white standard plate and the L*, a*, b* values were determined using the CIELAB color scale. The total color difference (ΔE) was calculated according to the (Eq.3) [14]:
Δ𝐸 = √(𝐿∗ − 𝐿2) + (𝑎∗ − 𝑎2) + (𝑏∗ − 𝑏2) (Eq.3)

sections.heading: 2. 10. UV-vis spectrophotometry
sections.text: Light transmission through the films (10 mm × 40 mm) was recorded between wavelength of 200-800 nm on an ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrophotometer (Speccord 210, Analytik AG, Jena, Germany).

sections.heading: 2.11. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA)
sections.text:
Thermogravimetric analysis of the different films was performed using a TGA Q500 instrument (TA Instruments, USA) running with the Universal Analysis Software. Each film (≈10 mg) was placed in a platinum pan and heated from room temperature to 800 ºC at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen flow of 70 mL/min.
2.12. Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC)
Differential scanning calorimetry was achieved in duplicate using a DSCQ100-RCS (TA Instruments, USA). Conditioned samples (RH 55%, 25 °C, 72 h) were placed (around 5 mg) in a hermetically sealed aluminum pan and heated and cooled at a rate of 10°C/min between 20 and 230 °C under a nitrogen flow (reference: an empty pan). The data were analyzed using the Thermal Analysis Universal 2000 software.

sections.heading: 2.13. Antifungal activity
sections.text:
Aspergillus niger (PTCC 5298) obtained from the culture collection at Iran Institute of Industrial and Scientific Research (Tehran, Iran). Antifungal activity was done as described by Arfat and associates [14] with some modifications. A Neubauer haemocytometer (Simax Kavalier) was used for the counting of spores. The antifungal activity of films on the medium culture against A. niger was determined by the disc diffusion method. PDA was poured into the petri-dishes and after solidification, fungal suspensions (100 µL, 106 CFU/mL) were spread on the culture media; the films were cut with a sterile punch (diameter 4 mm), then deposited on the medium surface. The plates were sealed by Parafilm® and stored at 25°C. The diameter of fungal growth was measured by a digital ruler after six days of incubation, and the percent of fungal growth inhibition was measured according to (Eq.4):
Fungal growth inhibition (%) = 𝑑𝑐−𝑑𝑡
𝑑𝑐 × 100 (Eq.4)
where dc and dt were fungal colony diameters in control and in the plates containing different films, respectively [29].

sections.heading: 2.14. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Statistics on a completely randomized design were performed with the analysis of variance (ANOVA) procedure in SPSS (version 16, SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL0 software). Duncan’s multiple range test (P < 0.05) was used to detect differences among mean values of films properties. Different letters show significant differences (P < 0.05).

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text: Chitosan and CMC were chosen as polymer matrix to the preparation of nanocomposite films containing ZnO NPs. All films were homogeneous, easily peeled from the petri-dishes, not brittle, and had good mechanical stability.

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD analysis
sections.text:
In order to study the structural properties of nanocomposite films, XRD analysis were done and the XRD patterns of ZnO NPs powder and CMC-CH-OL nanocomposites incorporated with ZnO NPs (0.5-2 wt.%) are shown in Figure 1. ZnO NPs powder showed 5 peaks at 2θ = 31.7º, 34.2º, 36.2º, 47.4º and 56.4° which represented different crystalline forms of ZnO. These peaks correspond to (100), (002), (101), (102) and (110) planes of zinc oxide, respectively. Strong and narrow peaks of ZnO NPs showed that it is crystalline in hexagonal wurtzite structure [30]. Previous studies [6, 30] are in agreement with our results. In addition, the size of ZnO NPs crystals was calculated according to the Scherrer’s equation were 23.23, 11.75, 12.12 and 11.49 nm, respectively and indicated approximately uniform size of crystals. All the tested films exhibited two characteristic diffraction peaks at around 2θ=9° and 2θ=20° corresponding to semi-crystalline polymer of chitosan in chitosan-CMC blend film [31, 32]. No change was observed in the position of both peaks after incorporation of ZnO NPs. Moreover, the peaks correspond to ZnO NPs were not seen in nanocomposite films, suggesting that the crystalline structure of polymer was not affected by the presence of ZnO NPs. However, after addition of small amounts of ZnO NPs (0.5wt.%), according to the Segal’s equation the percent of crystallinity decreased from 82.7% to 71.3% compared to the control, and then increased by adding higher amounts of ZnO NPs (1-2wt.%) to 78.2, and 87.8% for the nanocomposite films containing 1 and 2wt.% ZnO NPs, respectively. Disappearance of ZnO NPs peaks in the nanocomposites, could be attributed to the low concentration of ZnO NPs in material formulation. In addition, homogenous dispersing and distributing of ZnO NPs in polymer
matrix without aggregation and destroying of crystalline structure of ZnO NPs during film making process, and formation of some interactions between ZnO ions and hydroxyl groups of chitosan [33]. Representing the amorphous structure for nanocomposite films at low concentrations of ZnO NPs, have been reported in poly vinyl alcohol films incorporated with ZnO NPs [34], and poly lactic acid-ZnO NPs nanocomposite films [5], however they observed some peaks at higher concentrations of ZnO NPs. In addition, disappearance of ZnO NPs diffraction peaks has been reported in different nanocomposite films such as Kefiran [15]; and alginate [35] based films. Unlike to our results, the peaks corresponding to ZnO NPs was observed in soybean protein films [29], in addition, increase in the intensity of those peaks was shown with increasing ZnO NPs loading in the film formulations. Although, the concentration of ZnO NPs (5-15wt.%) in their study was higher than it is in our study (0.5-2wt.%).
Figure 1

sections.heading: 3.2. Morphology of films (SEM)
sections.text:
Figure 2 represents surface morphology of the pure CMC-CH-OL film and incorporated with 0.5 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs. The control film showed homogenous structure however, after addition of 0.5 wt.% ZnO NPs the structure changed to be rough but showed well distribution of ZnO NPs in the film matrix. Moreover, with increase in ZnO NPs loading in CMC-CH-OLZnO 2 wt.% some aggregations was seen in the matrix of polymer. It seems that, higher concentrations of ZnO NPs can form some aggregations in the polymer matrix. Low affinity between matrix of polymer and ZnO NPs were observed for soybean protein [29]; agar, carrageenan and CMC [36], and CMC-CH blend [13] films.
Figure 2
3.3. FTIR-ATR
The Infrared spectra of pure ZnO NPs powder and films of pure CMC and CH, CMC-CH blend, CMC-CH-OL containing ZnO NPs (0-2 wt.%), are shown in Figure 3 (a-b). The broad absorption band at 3323 and 3311 cm-1 for the CMC and chitosan films were attributed to stretching of O-H groups in CMC, and O-H and N-H groups in chitosan, changed to lower wavenumbers of 3270 and 3292 cm-1 in CMC-CH and CMC-CH-OL films, respectively, suggesting hydrogen bonding formation in blend films [14], between hydroxyl groups of chitosan and carboxyl groups of CMC. Moreover, after incorporation of ZnO NPs (0.5wt.%) into the polymer matrix, its wavenumber changed to 3351 cm-1, indicating existence of free OH groups in the surface of ZnO NPs. However with higher concentrations of ZnO NPs (1-2 wt.%), a shift to lower wavenumbers of 3346 and 3344 cm-1 was observed, confirmed some new hydrogen bonding formation between ZnO NPs and polymer matrix. Similar results have been reported for fish gelatin films incorporated with ZnO NPs and basil leaf essential oil [14]. In addition, differences between bands for ZnO NPs pure and nanocomposite films confirmed the formation of new interactions between ZnO NPs and the polymer matrix. A band at around at 1562 cm-1 for CMC-CH and CMC-CH-OL films corresponds to the N-H bending (amide II, bending vibration of N-H groups and stretching vibration of C-N groups) of chitosan. It was located at 1594 cm-1 for the CMC-CH-OL-ZnO NPs 0.5 wt.% and shifted to 1560 and 1546 cm1 for CMC-CH-OL-ZnO NPs 1 and 2wt.%, respectively, confirmed involving of -NH2 and -OH groups of chitosan and some new hydrogen formation between chitosan and ZnO NPs [37]. However, our results are in contrary to those of [38] for starch-ZnO NPs; and [39] for polyvinyl chloride-ZnO NPs based films, showed no differences between FTIR spectra after incorporation of ZnO NPs into the polymer matrix, and reported that there was no new bonding formation, just formation of physical interaction between ZnO NPs and polymer matrix.
Figure 3
3.4. Mechanical properties
The stress-strain curves of the films are presented in Figure 4, which indicates changing the mode of films from brittle to ductile. Also, mechanical properties of the bio nanocomposite films are shown in Table 1. Incorporation of ZnO NPs into polymer matrix had a significant effect on TS and EB of samples (P < 0.05). The TS for CMC-CH-OL film (7.34 MPa) was decreased significantly (P < 0.05) to 6.04, 4.32 and 1.92 MPa after incorporation of 0.5, 1 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs to the pure film, which corresponds to 17.7, 41.1 and 73.8% of reduction, respectively. However, EB was increased from 13.1% to 30.2, 42.3 and 41.5%, which associates to 56.4, 68.9 and 68.8% increase compared to the control film (CMC-CH-OL), respectively. Also, YM decreased from 55.9 to 41.2, 30.3 and 23.9 MPa for the films containing 0.5, 1 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs compared to the control one, indicated reduction in rigidity of nanocomposite films. Observations of these results are in agreement with the XRD patterns of the nanocomposite films, showed no peaks corresponding to ZnO NPs after addition of ZnO NPs to the polymer matrix. Our results are in good agreement with a study on agar, carrageenan and CMC based films which has reported decrease in the TS and YM and increase in EB of the films by incorporation of ZnO NPs [36]. They suggested that was probably due to the weak interfacial interaction between the polymer matrix and ZnO NPs, as well as plasticizing effect of ZnO NPs, which increased the movement of polymer chains. In addition, reduction in electrostatic interaction among the polymer chains in presence of ZnO NPs may reduce TS of films [35]. In another study, [40] a reduction in TS and increase in EB of calcium alginate-ZnO NPs films has been reported. Increase in SB could attribute to no interruption effect of ZnO NPs in the movement of polymer chains [36]. Unlike to our results, a significant increase in TS of CMC-CH-ZnO nanocomposite films has reported in comparison with CMC-CH film [13]. Comparison of our results with that study, show lessening effect of ZnO NPs on TS in our study, which could attribute to the presence of oleic acid with plasticizing effect, possibly led to reduction the enhancement effect of ZnO NPs. In contrast to our results, increase in TS and
decrease in EB by incorporation of ZnO NPs have been observed in cellulose [6]; starch [41]; fish gelatin [14]; and chitosan-CMC blend [13] based films. In another study, addition of ZnO NPs (0.1-0.5 wt.%) to chitosan films caused an increase in TS and EB [9]. These different results show that mechanical properties of film depend on many factors such as shape and concentration of nano particles, type of polymer matrix, distribution and the amount of inter and intermolecular interactions between chains of polymer, film forming conditions, and etc. [36, 41].
Figure 4 Table 1

sections.heading: 3.5. Contact angle
sections.text: Contact angle for the CMC-CH-OL film with different concentrations of ZnO NPs (0.5-2wt.%) are shown in Table 1. Additon of ZnO NPs as well as increase its concentration, had a positive effect on increase of the contact angle and it significantly (P < 0.05) increased from 22.9° in CMC-CH-OL to 33.7°, 47.4° and 58.9° for the nanocomposite films containing 0.5, 1 and 2wt.% ZnO NPs, respectively. These results indicate that addition of ZnO NPs led to decrease in tendency of surface to absorb water, also there was a positive relationship between increasing the contact angel and ZnO NPs loading. The contact angle of the films depends on surface hydrophobicity and roughness. The higher free hydrophillic groups cuase to lower contact angle of water with film surface. Our results are in good agreement with studies on CMC-CH-ZnO NPs [13] and starch-ZnO NPs nanocomposite films [8]. Packaging material with high contact angle and hydrophobe surface are sutable for food packaging, thus ZnO NPs showed a significant effect on contact angle which is favorable in food packaging application.

sections.heading: 3.6. Color properties
sections.text:
The color properties (L*, a* and b*), chroma (C*) and total color differences (ΔE*), of the CMC-CH-OL based nanocomposites incorporated with ZnO NPs (0.5-2 wt.%) are presented in
Table 2. With incorporation of ZnO NPs, L* value decreased, while a* and b* increased significantly (P < 0.05). These results indicated decrease in lightness of films as well as increase in greenness and yellowness of the films after addition of ZnO NPs. Comparison between all the films in C* and ΔE* showed that with increasing the concentration of ZnO NPs the intensity of color is increased in all the films. The results are in good agreement with those of [8, 36] reported reduction in L* and increase in a* and b* for neat agar, carrageenan, CMC; and starch based film, incorporated with ZnO NPs, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.7. Light transmittance
sections.text:
The UV-vis spectrophotometry results are shown in Table 2. The incorporation of ZnO NPs to the CMC-CH-OL matrix, led to a significant decline in light transmittance in both visible and UV ranges, although its effect was very impressive in UV compared to visible range. The control film (CMC-CH-OL) showed 17.2% UV transmittance at 280 nm which decreased to 0.2, 0.1 and 0.1% for nanocomposite films containing 0.5, 1, and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs respectively, indicating absorption almost 100% of UV light. This effect could be attributed to the quantum effect of ZnO NPs [41]. A slight reduction in transparency values at 600 nm was observed from 59.2 to 54.2, 53.7 and 49.7 % in CMC-CH-OL film and those containing 0.5, 1 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs, respectively. The results suggesting high UV protection capacity of nanocomposite films added ZnO NPs without much impact on their transparency which is favorite in food packaging application. Our results indicated that films containing 0.5 and 1% ZnO NPs showed excellent UV blocking activity with low effect on their transparency in visible range. Increase in UV barrier properties of films after addition of ZnO NPs have been shown for starch [38, 41]; kefiran [15]; gelatin [42] and agar, carrageenan and CMC [36] based films.
Table 2
3.8. Thermal properties

sections.heading: 3.8.1. Thermogravimetric analysis
sections.text:
The residual weight of different nanocomposite films as a function of temperature is shown in
thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and its derivative (DTG) (Figure 5-A). The results showed five steps in weight loss for CMC-CH-OL films and six steps for the nanocomposite films. The first weight loss step (Δw1 = 14.8-15.9%) around 98-109 °C was attributed to evaporation of residual water, acetic acid [43] as well as other volatile compounds in the films. The second weight loss (21.4-22.7%) around 200-212 °C which was not observed for the control film, could be associated with water attached to ZnO NPs [36, 44] also reduction of ZnO NPs by carbon [35]. The third weight loss step (15.8-36.7%) around 292-315 °C corresponded to degradation and decomposition of CMC and chitosan polymers and also decomposition of amino groups. The forth (6.2-8.6%) and fifth (13.7-16.9%) weight loss steps at around 340-363 °C and 495- 514 °C, respectively corresponded to the degradation of oleic acid and tween 80. TGA thermograms for pure oleic acid and tween 80 showed two steps of weight loss around 245 and 475 °C, and one step of weight loss at 405 °C for oleic acid and tween 80, respectively (results are not shown). The sixth weight loss step (9.4-15%) around 809-846 °C is related to degradation of CMC as well as highly stable compounds in the films. The results, showed that addition of ZnO NPs led to decrease in thermal stability of polymer matrix moreover, with an increase in ZnO NPs from 0.5 to 2 wt.%, there was a more reduction in thermal stability of polymer, and thus CMC-CH-OL-ZnO NPs 2 wt.% exhibited the lowest thermal stability among all samples. This phenomenon was related to the modification of polymer structure after incorporation of ZnO NPs. Decline in thermal stability of nanocomposite films might be due to plasticizing effect of ZnO NPs decreased the thermal stability of polymers. The results are in agreement with the lowered TS and higher SB of the nanocomposite films in compared to the control film. In contrast to our results, previous study [9] has shown increase in thermal stability of chitosan films incorporated with ZnO NPs (0.5 wt.%) and neem oil. The percent of residue
for CMC-CH-OL film increased from 14.7 to 14.9, 15.1 and 15.2 for films containing 0.5, 1.5 and 2% ZnO NPs, represented the presence of ZnO NPs in the films [31].
Figure 5

sections.heading: 3.8.2. . Differential Scanning Calorimetry
sections.text:
The DSC results of the films are shown in Figure (5-B). DSC thermogram for the pure chitosan film showed a slight endothermic peak at around 146.9 °C, which is related to the crystalline structure of chitosan as already shown by XRD (Figure 1). The neat CMC-based film showed a very broad endothermic region at around 125.6 °C. However, the CMC-CH blend film exhibited a single broad endothermic region at 118.8 °C, indicated homogeneity of films and miscibility among the major components [45] as already shown by FTIR results (Figure 3). Blending of chitosan with CMC could interrupt the rearrangement of polymer chain, which in turn, cause the formation of crystalline structure with weaker interaction resulting lower required energy for breaking them apart and lower melting temperature. The pure CMC-CHOL film and ones incorporated with ZnO NPs (0.5-2 wt.%) showed different thermograms. For the CMC-CH-OL the endothermic region was located at 193 ºC and could be attributed to starting the polymer degradation as shown by TGA results (Figure 5, A). However, after addition of ZnO NPs (0.5 wt.%), the endothermic region went to lower temperatures (183 ºC). The CMC-CH-OL film containing 1 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs, showed different endotherms compared to the former samples, indicating changing in the film structure in the presence of ZnO NPs. The endothermic regions at 139 and 131 ºC for CMC-CH-OL films containing 1 and 2 wt.% ZnO NPs could be attributed to the removing of water in ZnO NPs and reducing of ZnO NPs by carbon as shown by (TGA) results.
3.9. Antifungal properties
Antifungal properties of the CMC-CH-OL films without and with ZnO NPs were studied against A. niger by disc diffusion method. All the films clearly exhibited antifungal properties against the selected fungal strain (Table 3). The control film (CMC-CH-OL) showed antifungal properties (11.4 mm clear zone and 15.2% fungal growth inhibition) and it could be attributed to the antimicrobial properties of chitosan. The antimicrobial property of chitosan is related to interactions between its positive charges and the negative charges of microbial membranes that lead to disruption of cell walls. Previous study [46] have reported antifungal properties of chitosan with low molecular weight. Low molecular weight chitosan can enter to the hypha of Fulvia fulva and lead to death of the organism from inside of the cell [46]. In another study [31] antimicrobial activity of chitosan-cellulose blend film against S. aureus and E. coli have been observed. In contrast to our results, in another study [13] no antibacterial properties of CMCCH films have exhibited. It seems that presence of oleic acid in our study, had some effects on antimicrobial properties of CMC-CH-OL film. Oleic acid can coat ZnO NPs and prevents the agglomeration of particles which lead to good dispersion of ZnO NPs, then facilitates release of ZnO NPs in the polymer matrix [37]. In addition, this fatty acid confront from antimicrobial properties, which has synergistic effect in the presence of chitosan. After addition of 0.5 wt.% ZnO NPs, to the control film (CMC-CH-OL) the inhibition zone (mm) and fungal growth inhibition (%) increased significantly (P < 0.05) from 11.4 to 22.7 mm, and 15.2 to 31.3%, respectively. There was a positive correspondence between antifungal properties and concentration of ZnO NPs, which the highest antifungal property was observed in the bionanocomposites containing 2 wt.% ZnO NPs with 30.1 mm inhibition zone and 40.1% inhibition. Antimicrobial properties of ZnO NPs could be attributed to different mechanisms, however the exact mechanism of antifungal activity of ZnO NPs has not obviously understood. The most important mechanism is related to the electrostatic bonding of Zn+2 ions to the microorganism cell surface, which cause change in the permeability of cell membrane, damage
cell membrane after penetration of ZnO NPs thorough the cell, as well as interact with respiratory enzymes and inactivate them, react with cell components, and deplete cytoplasmic contents [14, 30]. Moreover, the photocatalytic generation of a huge numbers of superoxide anions and hydroxyl radicals, generation of hydrogen peroxide (strong oxidizing agent) and formation of Zn2+ ions are some of probable antimicrobial mechanisms of ZnO NPs [5]. Previous study [47] have reported the antifungal properties of ZnO NPs against Botrytis cinerea and Penicillium expansum. They observed deformation in fungal hyphae and changing in cellular actions of B. cinerea growth and inhibition of ZnO NPs on the conidiophores and conidia growth of P. expansum, which led to fungal death. It seems that deformation of fungal structure caused by extreme accumulation of nucleic acid and carbohydrate where produced to stress response of fungal cell [48]. In addition, synergistic effects between chitosan and ZnO NPs led to increase the antibacterial activity of ZnO NPs by faciliting ZnO NPs adhesion to the cell membrane through NH2 groups of chitosan [49]. Unlike to our results, no antifungal effects of polyvinyl chloride films coated with ZnO NPs against Aspergillus flavus and Penicillium citrinum could attribute to the absence of light during an experiment probably led to lack of active oxygen production due to the stop of photocatalytic reaction under dark conditions [12].
Table 3

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
The aim of this study was to prepare and characterize nanocomposite-films based on CMC-CHOL incorporated with different concentrations of ZnO NPs (0.5-2% wt.%). Mechanical tests showed an increase in the extensibility of films in the presence of ZnO NPs. Reduction in thermal stability of nanocomposite films were obtained by TGA and DSC tests, showed the plasticizing effect of ZnO NPs on the polymer network. Water contact angle of films improved in the presence of ZnO NPs. Addition of ZnO NPs led to a considerable absorbance of UV light at all tested concentrations of ZnO NPs with low adverse effect on the transparency of films in
the visible range. Microbial tests represented superior antifungal activity of nanocomposite films especially at the highest concentrations of ZnO NPs (2 wt. %). Considering the obtained results, production of biodegradable active packaging based on CMC-CH-OL-ZnO NPs is a promising method for food preservation.
5. Acknowledgment: The authors acknowledge the Universities of Tabriz and Bu Ali Sina, and Iran nanotechnology initiative council for their financial supports. Nooshin Noshirvani acknowledges Dr Christian Gardrat (University of Bordeaux, CNRS, LCPO, UMR 5629, F33600 Pessac, France) for his kind assistance.

references.venue: Antimicrobial Activity and food packaging applications, Food Bioprocess Tech. 5

referenceMentions.context: Microbial contamination of food is a serious problem which causes health problems for consumers and decreases food shelf life [1].

However, due to probable problems of synthetic preservatives to human health, consumers are looking for bio-based and generally recognized as safe (GRAS) preservatives to control the microbial growth of food [2].
Active food packaging includes interaction between food and packaging material, which inhibits microbial growth of food and increases its shelf life [3].
There has been much interest in the use of metal nanoparticles in this type of packaging, due to fact that metal oxide nanoparticles show excellent antimicrobial properties [4].
Among them, application of gold and silver as antimicrobial agent, is limited due to their high price [5].
Also, it is known as a GRAS compound by Food and Drug Administration [6].
It is worth noting that because ZnO NPs use as nutrient agent, thus addition of it to the film packaging and its probable diffusion to the food products are not harmful to human health [7].
The effective antimicrobial properties of ZnO NPs in active films have been reported for starch films against Staphylococcus aureus [8];
3 polylactic acid-ZnO NPs nanocomposite films against Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus [5]; chitosan-neem oil based film against E.
coli [9]; and sodium alginate-gum acacia hydrogels versus Pseudomonas aerigunosa and Bacillus cereus [10].
coli [9]; and sodium alginate-gum acacia hydrogels versus Pseudomonas aerigunosa and Bacillus cereus [10].
The main reason for superior antimicrobial properties of metal nanoparticles is connected to their high surface area [11].
Thus, it is important to study the antifungal effects of ZnO NPs [12], while few studies have been done on it.
Incorporation of ZnO NPs in biopolymer matrix is not only for its antimicrobial effects, but also for enhancing the mechanical and barrier properties of the bio nanocomposites as filler [13].
Previous studies have shown that the ZnO NPs can improve the mechanical [6, 13], barrier [5, 8, 14, 15]; and thermal properties [9, 14] of nanocomposite films.

Chitosan film is a good barrier to oxygen and CO2 at low relative humidity, due to its ordered and packed structure and high hydrophilicity [21].
However, low water barrier properties is one of the disadvantages of polysaccharide films like chitosan [22], which can be improved by blending chitosan with other polymers.
